title: Monochromatic Red Beauty Photo Deconstruction
summary: Professional photographer Lindsay Adler breaks down the lighting, styling, and post-processing techniques used to create a dramatic monochromatic red beauty portrait using a four-light setup.

steps.action: Construct the set using a Savage Universal Primary Red background and a red plexiglass mirror surface for reflections.
steps.tool: Savage Universal Primary Red Background, Red Plexiglass

steps.action: Set up the main light using a Profoto D2 with a Westcott Optical Spot and a 150mm lens, slightly defocused to create a soft slice of light on the face.
steps.tool: Profoto D2, Westcott Optical Spot, 150mm Lens

steps.action: Position a rim/shoulder light overhead using a Profoto D2 with a medium umbrella and diffusion to create separation.
Place a background light behind the subject using a Profoto B10+ with an ND gel to cut power and create a subtle glow.
Add a fill light to the right using a Profoto B10+ with a medium umbrella, diffusion, and a red gel to lift shadows without losing color saturation.
steps.tool: Profoto B10+, Medium Umbrella, Red Gel

steps.action: Set camera settings to 1/200 sec, f/8, ISO 400.
Perform post-processing: Adjust white balance (warmer with magenta tint), retouch skin texture emphasized by hard light, and unify skin tones.

key_takeaways: Do not over-light saturated red backgrounds, as it can wash out the color or turn it orange.
Use Neutral Density (ND) gels to reduce strobe power below its minimum setting for subtle effects.
Hard lighting sources like optical spots will emphasize skin texture, requiring careful retouching.
Monochromatic images rely on texture, depth, and varied lighting to create visual interest.
